nodes.question: System shows no signs of life (no fans, LEDs, or sounds). First step: Check if the wall outlet works by plugging in another device.

knowledge.text: Plug a lamp, phone charger, or any device into the same outlet. If it powers on, your outlet is good. If not, try another outlet or check your breaker.

nodes.result: The outlet has no power. Reset your breaker, check if it's a switched outlet, or move to a known-good outlet before continuing.

knowledge.text: Check your electrical panel for tripped breakers. Some outlets are controlled by wall switches - make sure the switch is on. Test with a different outlet to confirm power.

nodes.question: Check the PSU rear switch - is it in the ON position (I)?

knowledge.text: On the back of your PSU is a rocker switch. Make sure it's in the 'I' (on) position, not 'O' (off). If your PSU has a 115V/230V voltage selector, ensure it matches your region: 115V for US/Canada/Japan, 230V for EU/UK/Australia.

nodes.question: Verify the 24-pin ATX and 8-pin CPU (EPS) connectors are fully seated in the motherboard.

knowledge.text: The 24-pin ATX connector is the large one on the motherboard edge. The 8-pin EPS (sometimes 4+4 pin) plugs in near the CPU socket. Push firmly until they click into place. CRITICAL: If your PSU is modular, only use cables that came with YOUR specific PSU model - never mix cables from different PSUs.

nodes.question: Perform the PSU paperclip test. Does the PSU fan spin when jumped?

knowledge.text: Unplug PSU from wall and motherboard. On the 24-pin connector, use a bent paperclip or wire to bridge the green wire to any black wire (ground). Plug PSU back into wall and flip the switch to ON. If the fan spins, the PSU can turn on by itself. If you have a spare PSU, you can swap it in instead to test.

nodes.result: PSU failed the paperclip test. The power supply is dead and needs to be replaced.

knowledge.text: If the PSU doesn't start during the paperclip test, it's faulty. Replace it with a quality unit that meets or exceeds your system's power requirements. Use a PSU calculator online if unsure about wattage needs.

nodes.question: Bypass the case power button: short the PWR_SW pins on the motherboard with a screwdriver. Does it power on?

knowledge.text: Locate the front panel header pins (usually bottom-right of motherboard, labeled F_PANEL or JFP1). Use your motherboard manual to find the PWR_SW pins. Touch both pins briefly with a screwdriver tip. If it powers on, your case button or wiring is faulty. If not, the motherboard may not be receiving power properly.

nodes.question: Remove motherboard from case and test on cardboard or wood (breadboard test). Does it show any signs of life?

knowledge.text: Power off and unplug everything. Remove motherboard from case. Place it on a cardboard box or wooden surface (non-conductive). Install only CPU with cooler and 1 stick of RAM. Connect 24-pin ATX and 8-pin EPS from PSU. Short the PWR_SW pins to test. If it works outside the case, you have a short circuit inside the case.

nodes.result: System works outside the case but not inside = short circuit in case. Check motherboard standoff placement and ensure no extra standoffs under the board where there are no mounting holes. Also check for loose screws between motherboard and case.

knowledge.text: Only install standoffs where the motherboard has mounting holes. Extra standoffs touching the back of the PCB cause shorts. Remove all standoffs, then reinstall only the ones that align with motherboard holes. Make sure no metal is touching the back of the motherboard.

nodes.result: No power even when breadboarded = dead motherboard or CPU. Try swapping with known-good parts if available, otherwise both components need replacement.

knowledge.text: If the system shows no life even outside the case with minimal components, either the motherboard or CPU (or both) are dead. These parts cannot be easily tested without spare hardware. Consider taking it to a repair shop for component testing, or replace motherboard first as it's the more common failure point.

nodes.question: NEW BUILD: System powers on then shuts off in less than 1 second. First check: Are motherboard standoffs installed correctly with no extras touching the board?

knowledge.text: Only install standoffs where the motherboard has mounting holes. Extra standoffs or screws between the motherboard and case cause instant shorts and shutdowns. Remove all standoffs, then reinstall only the ones that align with motherboard mounting holes.

nodes.question: Is the CPU cooler properly mounted? Remove and remount the cooler, ensuring it's making contact with the CPU.

knowledge.text: Remove the CPU cooler. Clean off old thermal paste with isopropyl alcohol. Apply a pea-sized amount of new thermal paste to the center of the CPU. Remount the cooler, tightening screws in an X pattern evenly. Make sure the cooler's pump/fan header is plugged into CPU_FAN on the motherboard - some boards won't boot without detecting a CPU fan.

nodes.question: PSU may be failing under load. Try a different PSU if available. Does it stay on?

knowledge.text: A PSU can pass the paperclip test (no load) but fail when components draw power. Borrow a PSU from another PC or friend to test. Make sure it has sufficient wattage for your components (especially GPU).

nodes.question: Remove all RAM and try to power on. Does it stay on longer or beep?

knowledge.text: Remove all RAM sticks completely. Try to power on. If the system stays on longer or beeps (no RAM detected), the RAM or CPU is the issue. If it still instantly shuts off with no RAM, it's likely a motherboard short, bad CPU installation, or PSU overload protection.

nodes.result: Instant shutdown with no RAM installed = CPU installation issue, motherboard short, or PSU protection triggering. Check CPU is seated correctly with no bent pins (Intel) or bent pads (AMD). Verify no debris under CPU. Breadboard test outside case if not already done.

knowledge.text: Remove CPU cooler and CPU. Inspect CPU socket pins (Intel) or CPU pins (AMD) for bent pins. Check for debris. Reseat CPU carefully, ensuring it's oriented correctly (look for triangle markers). Ensure CPU cooler backplate isn't causing board flex that shorts components.

nodes.question: System was working, now shuts off instantly. First: Disconnect the RESET switch from the motherboard header. Does it stay on?

knowledge.text: A stuck or shorted RESET switch causes instant power cycling. Locate the front panel header (F_PANEL) on your motherboard and remove the RESET_SW connector. Leave PWR_SW connected. Try powering on. If it works, your reset button or cable is faulty.

nodes.question: Check all power cables are fully seated (24-pin ATX, 8-pin EPS, GPU power). Reseat everything. Does it stay on?

knowledge.text: Cables can work loose over time from vibration or case movement. Check: 24-pin ATX (main motherboard power), 8-pin EPS (CPU power near socket), PCIe 6/8-pin (GPU power if you have a graphics card). Push each connector firmly until it clicks.

nodes.question: Disconnect all drives and remove GPU (if using integrated graphics). Does it stay on?

knowledge.text: Unplug all SATA data and power cables from drives. If you have integrated graphics, remove the dedicated GPU completely. Try booting with minimal hardware: motherboard, CPU, cooler, 1 RAM stick, PSU. If it stays on, one of the removed components is causing the shutdown.

nodes.result: System stays on with components removed = one of those components has failed. Add them back one at a time to identify which one causes the shutdown. Most common culprits: GPU, hard drive, or a bad SATA cable.

knowledge.text: Power off. Add one component back at a time: first GPU, then drives one by one. Power on after each addition. When it shuts off instantly again, you've found the failed component.

nodes.result: Instant shutdown with minimal components = PSU failing under load or motherboard failure. Test with a known-good PSU first. If problem persists, motherboard needs replacement.

knowledge.text: A PSU can degrade over time and trigger overload protection even with normal loads. Capacitors fail, especially in cheaper units. If a different PSU doesn't fix it, the motherboard has likely failed.

nodes.question: System powers on then cycles/reboots repeatedly. First step: Reseat all RAM sticks. Does it POST?

knowledge.text: Power off and unplug PSU. Press case power button to discharge. Open case and remove all RAM sticks - push down the clips at each end and pull straight up. Reinsert RAM firmly into the slots (usually slots A2 and B2 for dual channel) until clips snap closed. You should hear a click.

nodes.question: Try booting with a single RAM stick in slot A2 (second slot from CPU). Does it POST?

knowledge.text: Remove all RAM except one stick. Check your motherboard manual for the recommended single-stick slot (usually A2, the second slot from the CPU socket). Insert the stick firmly until it clicks. Try each RAM stick individually if this doesn't work - one may be bad.

nodes.result: System POSTs with one stick but not all sticks = either you have a bad RAM stick or incompatible RAM configuration. Test each stick individually in slot A2 to find the bad one. If all sticks work individually, try them in pairs and check your motherboard's QVL for RAM compatibility.

knowledge.text: Test each stick one at a time in slot A2. Mark which ones work and which cause cycling. Bad stick(s) need replacement. If all work individually but fail together, check motherboard QVL (Qualified Vendor List) for RAM compatibility and try enabling XMP/DOCP in BIOS.

nodes.question: Clear CMOS and wait 3-5 minutes with system powered on (it may reboot several times during memory training). Does it eventually POST?

knowledge.text: Turn off PSU switch. Press case power button to discharge capacitors. Remove the round CMOS battery for 2 minutes (or use CLR_CMOS jumper/button per manual). Replace battery, turn on PSU, and boot. DO NOT turn off during the first 3-5 minutes - DDR5 and AM5/Intel 12th+ gen platforms take time to train memory and may reboot 2-3 times automatically. This is normal.

nodes.question: Verify CPU 8-pin EPS power cable is fully seated. Reseat if needed. Does it POST?

knowledge.text: Locate the 8-pin (or 4+4 pin) EPS connector near the CPU socket. Push firmly until it clicks. DO NOT confuse this with PCIe 8-pin GPU power - they look similar but are keyed differently. Using the wrong cable can damage components.

nodes.question: Remove GPU (if using integrated graphics) and disconnect all drives. Does it stop cycling?

knowledge.text: Unplug all SATA cables from motherboard. If you have integrated graphics on your CPU, remove the dedicated GPU completely (unscrew from case, release PCIe latch, unplug power cables). Try booting with just CPU, RAM, and motherboard.

nodes.result: Cycling stops when GPU or drives removed = faulty GPU or drive. Add components back one at a time to identify the culprit.

knowledge.text: Add back one component at a time: GPU first, then drives. When cycling returns, you've found the failed component. Bad drives or GPUs drawing excessive power can cause cycling.

nodes.result: Cycling continues with minimal components = CPU compatibility issue, bent CPU pins, bad motherboard, or RAM incompatibility. Check CPU is on motherboard's supported CPU list. Inspect CPU socket/pins. Test with known-good RAM if possible. Motherboard replacement may be necessary.

knowledge.text: Remove CPU and inspect socket pins (Intel) or CPU pins (AMD) carefully with a flashlight. Even one bent pin causes cycling. For AMD, gently straighten bent pins with a mechanical pencil tip or credit card edge. For Intel, pins are in the socket - much harder to fix. Check motherboard's CPU support list on manufacturer website.

nodes.question: Fans spin to maximum speed immediately. Check CPU 8-pin EPS power cable is connected and seated. Is it connected?

knowledge.text: Fans at max speed means the motherboard cannot detect or communicate with the CPU. First check: 8-pin EPS power near the CPU socket. This is separate from the 24-pin ATX connector. Without CPU power, the board cannot initialize and runs fans at 100% as a safety measure.

nodes.question: Is the CPU cooler properly mounted with thermal paste and plugged into CPU_FAN header?

knowledge.text: Check: 1) CPU cooler fan is plugged into CPU_FAN header on motherboard (not CHA_FAN or SYS_FAN). 2) Cooler is mounted firmly with even pressure. 3) Thermal paste is applied between CPU and cooler. Some motherboards won't boot without detecting a CPU fan.

nodes.question: Reseat the CPU. Remove cooler, inspect for bent pins or debris, reinstall CPU carefully. Does it POST?

knowledge.text: Remove cooler and CPU. Inspect CPU socket pins (Intel) or CPU pins (AMD) for bends. Check for debris in socket. Clean old thermal paste off CPU and cooler with isopropyl alcohol. Reinstall CPU, aligning triangle markers. Apply pea-sized thermal paste. Remount cooler.

nodes.question: Does your motherboard need a BIOS update to support this CPU? Check manufacturer website. If board has BIOS Flashback, update BIOS now.

knowledge.text: Check motherboard manufacturer website for CPU support list. Newer CPUs often need BIOS updates. If your board has BIOS Flashback (USB port with button), download latest BIOS to USB drive (FAT32 format, rename per manual), plug into Flashback port, and press button for 5 seconds. Process takes 5-10 minutes - do not power off.

nodes.result: Fans at max with CPU power connected and cooler mounted = CPU not detected. Likely dead CPU, incompatible CPU, or dead motherboard. Test with known-good CPU if possible. Check motherboard's CPU compatibility list.

knowledge.text: If all power is connected, cooler is mounted, and BIOS is up to date, the CPU or motherboard is faulty. This requires testing with spare parts. Dead CPUs are rare but happen. More often it's bent pins or motherboard failure.

nodes.question: NEW BUILD with no display. Does your motherboard need a BIOS update to support this CPU? Check manufacturer website. Does it have BIOS Flashback?

knowledge.text: MOST COMMON NEW BUILD ISSUE: Motherboard needs BIOS update for new CPU. Check motherboard box for 'Ryzen 5000 Ready' or similar sticker. If not present, BIOS update is needed. Use BIOS Flashback if available (USB port with button on rear I/O). Download BIOS from manufacturer site, copy to FAT32 USB drive, rename per manual, plug into flashback port, press button 5 seconds.

nodes.question: Reseat all RAM sticks firmly until clips snap. Does it POST?

knowledge.text: RAM not fully seated is the #1 beginner mistake. Push down HARD on both ends of each stick until you hear and feel the clips snap closed on both sides. It takes more force than you think. The stick should be level and flush with the slot.

nodes.question: Try one RAM stick in slot A2 (second from CPU). Does it POST?

knowledge.text: Remove all RAM except one stick. Install in slot A2 (usually second from CPU - check manual). Try different sticks if first doesn't work. One stick may be DOA (dead on arrival).

nodes.question: Is monitor plugged into the GPU (not motherboard) and set to correct input? Try different cable/port.

knowledge.text: NEW BUILDER MISTAKE: If you have a graphics card installed, the motherboard video ports are DISABLED. Plug monitor cable into the GPU (the card in the PCIe slot), not the motherboard. Make sure monitor is on and set to the correct input (HDMI 1, DP, etc.). Try a different cable if possible.

nodes.question: Is GPU power cable (6-pin or 8-pin) connected? Is GPU firmly seated in top PCIe slot?

knowledge.text: Most GPUs need PCIe power cables (6-pin, 8-pin, or 12-pin connectors on the side of the card). Make sure they're fully plugged in - some require TWO 8-pin cables. Also verify GPU is pushed all the way into the top PCIe x16 slot until the latch clicks. You may need to press firmly.

nodes.question: Clear CMOS and wait 3-5 minutes for memory training. Does it POST?

knowledge.text: Turn off PSU switch. Remove CMOS battery for 2 minutes or use CLR_CMOS jumper/button. Replace battery and boot. WAIT 3-5 minutes without touching anything - DDR5 and new platforms reboot multiple times during memory training. This is normal. Don't power off during this time.

nodes.question: Remove CPU cooler and CPU. Inspect for bent pins (AMD) or socket pins (Intel). Any visible damage?

knowledge.text: AMD CPUs have pins on the CPU - inspect the bottom with a flashlight. Intel CPUs have pins in the socket - inspect the socket. Even ONE bent pin prevents boot. AMD pins can be carefully straightened with a mechanical pencil tip or credit card edge. Intel socket pins are nearly impossible to fix - usually means RMA. Also check for debris or plastic film still covering socket.

nodes.result: New build troubleshooting exhausted. Most likely: 1) DOA (dead on arrival) motherboard, 2) DOA CPU, 3) RAM incompatibility - check motherboard QVL list, 4) All cables not connected (recheck EVERYTHING). If all cables are confirmed good, test components individually if you have spare parts, or contact retailer for RMA.

knowledge.text: New builds with no display after all troubleshooting usually have a DOA component. Contact your retailer within return window. Most common DOA parts in order: motherboard, RAM, CPU. Double-check one last time: CPU 8-pin power connected, GPU power connected, RAM fully seated, monitor plugged into GPU not motherboard.

nodes.question: Fans spin but no display, no debug features. First: Is monitor cable plugged into the correct port and monitor set to right input?

knowledge.text: If you have a dedicated GPU, plug monitor into the GPU outputs (not motherboard). If using integrated graphics, plug into motherboard. Check monitor is powered on and set to correct input (press Input/Source button on monitor). Try a different cable (HDMI/DisplayPort) and different port if available.

nodes.question: Unplug ALL USB devices except keyboard (remove mice, drives, dongles, hubs, etc.). Any change?

knowledge.text: Faulty USB devices (especially front-panel USB headers, card readers, or cheap hubs) can prevent POST. Unplug everything from rear USB ports and disconnect front-panel USB header from motherboard. Leave only keyboard. If it boots, add devices back one at a time to find the culprit.

nodes.question: Reseat all RAM sticks. Does it POST?

knowledge.text: Power off and unplug PSU. Remove all RAM sticks - push down clips at ends and pull straight up. Reinsert firmly until clips snap closed on both sides. Push harder than you think - they need force to fully seat.

nodes.question: Try one RAM stick in slot A2. Does it POST?

knowledge.text: Remove all RAM except one stick. Install in slot A2 (second slot from CPU - check motherboard manual). If it doesn't work, try each stick individually - one may be bad. Also try different slots.

nodes.question: Clear CMOS and wait 3-5 minutes. Does it POST?

knowledge.text: Turn off PSU switch. Press case button to discharge. Remove CMOS battery for 2 minutes (or use CLR_CMOS jumper/button per manual). Replace battery, turn on PSU, boot. WAIT 3-5 minutes - newer platforms take time to train memory and may reboot automatically. Don't interrupt this process.

nodes.question: Verify GPU power cables connected and GPU fully seated in top PCIe slot. Does it POST?

knowledge.text: Check GPU has PCIe power cables connected (6-pin, 8-pin, or 12-pin on side of card). Some GPUs need two cables. Push GPU firmly into top PCIe x16 slot until latch clicks. Release latch at back of slot, remove GPU, and reinstall if unsure.

nodes.question: Remove GPU and plug monitor into motherboard ports to test integrated graphics. Does it POST?

knowledge.text: Power off. Remove GPU completely (unscrew from case, release PCIe latch, unplug power cables). Plug monitor cable into motherboard video ports (HDMI/DP on rear I/O). This only works if your CPU has integrated graphics (Intel F-series and AMD non-G CPUs do NOT have iGPU).

nodes.result: System works with integrated graphics but not with GPU = dead or incompatible GPU. Try GPU in a different PCIe slot. If still no display, GPU needs replacement or testing in another system.

knowledge.text: If integrated graphics works but GPU doesn't, the GPU is likely dead or not getting proper power. Verify PSU has enough wattage for GPU. Try GPU in second PCIe slot if available. Test GPU in friend's PC if possible.

nodes.question: Verify CPU 8-pin EPS power cable is fully seated near CPU socket. Does it POST?

knowledge.text: Locate 8-pin (or 4+4 pin) EPS connector near CPU socket. Push firmly until it clicks. This is separate from 24-pin ATX. Do NOT confuse with PCIe 8-pin GPU power - they look similar but are keyed differently.

nodes.question: Remove CPU cooler and CPU. Inspect for bent pins. Reinstall carefully. Does it POST?

knowledge.text: Remove cooler and CPU. Inspect CPU socket pins (Intel) or CPU pins (AMD) with flashlight for bends or debris. Clean off thermal paste with isopropyl alcohol. Reinstall CPU aligned properly (triangle markers). Apply new thermal paste (pea-sized). Remount cooler with even pressure.

nodes.question: Try each RAM stick in every slot individually. Any POST?

knowledge.text: This isolates bad RAM sticks and bad motherboard slots. Test each stick one at a time in each slot: Stick 1 in A1, A2, B1, B2. Then Stick 2 in all slots, etc. Mark which combinations work. A bad slot or stick will reveal itself.

nodes.result: All troubleshooting exhausted. Suspect dead motherboard, CPU, or incompatible RAM. Breadboard test outside case if not done already. Test with known-good components if available. Most likely needs motherboard or CPU replacement.

knowledge.text: If breadboard test was not done: remove motherboard from case, place on cardboard, install only CPU + cooler + 1 RAM + power. If still no POST, either motherboard, CPU, or RAM is dead. Without spare parts to swap test, you'll need professional diagnosis or start replacing parts (motherboard first as most common failure).

nodes.question: What beep pattern do you hear?

knowledge.text: Beep codes vary by BIOS manufacturer (AMI, Award, Phoenix). Count the beeps carefully - long vs short matters. Patterns indicate which component failed to initialize: RAM, GPU, or CPU most commonly.

nodes.question: Beep code indicates RAM issue. Reseat all RAM sticks. Does beeping stop and system POST?

knowledge.text: Remove all RAM sticks and reinsert firmly until clips snap closed. Push harder than you think - they need significant force.

nodes.question: Try one RAM stick at a time in slot A2. Does it POST?

knowledge.text: Test each stick individually in slot A2. If one works, the others are bad. If none work, either all RAM is bad (rare) or motherboard RAM slots are faulty.

nodes.result: RAM beep code persists with all troubleshooting = dead motherboard RAM controller or incompatible RAM. Check motherboard QVL (Qualified Vendor List) for RAM compatibility. Test with known-good RAM if available.

knowledge.text: If beeping continues with known-good RAM or different RAM, the motherboard's memory controller is likely dead. Check manufacturer website for your motherboard's QVL to ensure RAM is compatible.

nodes.question: Beep code indicates GPU issue. Is GPU power connected and card fully seated?

knowledge.text: Check PCIe power cables are connected to GPU (6-pin, 8-pin, or 12-pin). Push GPU firmly into top PCIe x16 slot until it clicks.

nodes.question: Remove GPU and use integrated graphics. Does beeping stop?

knowledge.text: Remove GPU completely. Connect monitor to motherboard ports. Only works if CPU has integrated graphics.

nodes.result: GPU beep code persists = dead motherboard PCIe slot or incompatible GPU. Try GPU in different PCIe slot. Test GPU in another system if possible.

knowledge.text: If GPU works in another PC, your motherboard's PCIe slot is dead. If GPU doesn't work anywhere, GPU is dead.

nodes.question: Beep code indicates CPU issue. Is CPU 8-pin EPS power connected?

knowledge.text: Check 8-pin EPS power near CPU socket is fully seated. Do not confuse with PCIe 8-pin GPU power.

nodes.question: Reseat CPU. Inspect for bent pins. Does beeping stop?

knowledge.text: Remove cooler and CPU. Inspect socket/CPU pins for bends or debris. Reinstall CPU carefully with proper alignment.

nodes.result: CPU beep code persists = dead CPU, bent pins, or dead motherboard CPU socket. Check CPU compatibility with motherboard. Test with known-good CPU if available.

knowledge.text: CPU failures are rare. More likely: bent pins (AMD) or incompatible CPU needing BIOS update. Check motherboard's CPU support list.

nodes.result: Unrecognized beep pattern. Consult your motherboard manual's beep code table or manufacturer website. Each BIOS vendor (AMI, Award, Phoenix) has different codes.

knowledge.text: Search for your motherboard model + 'beep codes' to find the specific meaning. Manual usually has a table in troubleshooting section.

nodes.question: Which debug LED is lit or stays lit the longest?

knowledge.text: Most modern boards have 4 debug LEDs labeled CPU, DRAM, VGA, BOOT. During POST, they light up in sequence. The one that stays lit indicates where POST is failing. Watch carefully - sometimes they cycle fast.

nodes.question: CPU LED is lit. Is CPU 8-pin EPS power connected?

knowledge.text: CPU LED means CPU not detected. First check: 8-pin EPS power near CPU socket. This is separate from 24-pin ATX.

nodes.question: Reseat CPU and check for bent pins. CPU LED go off?

knowledge.text: Remove cooler and CPU. Inspect for bent pins or debris. Reinstall carefully with proper alignment.

nodes.question: Does motherboard need BIOS update for this CPU? Try BIOS Flashback if available.

knowledge.text: Check motherboard website for CPU support. Download latest BIOS to FAT32 USB drive, use BIOS Flashback port and button per manual.

nodes.result: CPU LED stays lit after all checks = dead CPU, bent pins not visible, or dead motherboard. Test with known-good CPU if possible.

knowledge.text: CPU failures are rare. More likely bent pins or incompatibility. Without spare CPU to test, both CPU and motherboard are suspect.

nodes.question: DRAM LED is lit. Reseat all RAM sticks. Does LED go off?

knowledge.text: DRAM LED means RAM not detected. Remove and firmly reinsert all sticks until clips snap.

nodes.question: Try one RAM stick in slot A2. Does DRAM LED go off?

knowledge.text: Test each stick individually in slot A2. One may be dead.

nodes.question: Clear CMOS and wait 3-5 minutes. Does DRAM LED go off?

knowledge.text: Clear CMOS and wait - DDR5 and newer platforms take time for memory training. May reboot several times automatically.

nodes.result: DRAM LED stays lit = dead RAM slots on motherboard or incompatible RAM. Check motherboard QVL for RAM compatibility. Test with known-good RAM if possible.

knowledge.text: If LED persists with known-good RAM, motherboard memory controller is dead.

nodes.question: VGA LED is lit. Is GPU power connected and card fully seated?

knowledge.text: VGA LED means GPU not detected. Check PCIe power cables and ensure GPU is pushed fully into top PCIe slot.

nodes.question: Remove GPU and use integrated graphics. Does VGA LED go off?

knowledge.text: Remove GPU, connect monitor to motherboard. Only works if CPU has integrated graphics.

nodes.result: VGA LED stays lit = dead GPU or dead PCIe slot. Try GPU in different slot. Test GPU in another PC if possible.

knowledge.text: If GPU works elsewhere, motherboard PCIe slot is bad. If GPU fails everywhere, GPU is dead.

nodes.question: BOOT LED is lit. Disconnect all storage drives except boot drive. Does LED go off?

knowledge.text: BOOT LED means system POSTed but can't find bootable drive. Unplug all SATA/NVMe drives except OS drive. Bad drives can block boot.

nodes.question: Enter BIOS (spam Del/F2 at startup) and check boot order. Is OS drive listed first?

knowledge.text: Restart and immediately press Delete or F2 repeatedly to enter BIOS. Navigate to Boot menu. Ensure your OS drive is first in boot priority. Save and exit.

nodes.result: OS drive not detected in BIOS = dead drive, loose cable, or bad M.2 slot. Check SATA data/power cables are connected. For M.2 drives, reseat in slot. Try drive in different SATA port or M.2 slot. Drive may be dead - test in another PC if possible.

knowledge.text: For SATA drives: check both SATA data cable (to motherboard) and SATA power cable (from PSU) are connected. For M.2 NVMe: remove screw, pull drive out, reinsert firmly, screw down. Some M.2 slots share lanes with SATA ports - check manual.

nodes.result: All LEDs cycle through then system POSTs = normal behavior. If you're seeing display and can enter BIOS, POST is successful. The LEDs are supposed to light up sequentially during POST.

knowledge.text: Debug LEDs lighting up briefly in sequence (CPU  DRAM  VGA  BOOT) is normal POST behavior. Only if one stays lit is there a problem.

nodes.result: Your motherboard has a debug code display showing hex codes. Common codes: 00 or FF = initialization, A0-A2 = IDE detect, 15 = pre-memory, 53-55 = memory issues, 62-66 = CPU issues, 94-99 = PCIe issues. Consult your motherboard manual's POST code table for exact meaning of the code displayed.

knowledge.text: The 2-digit hex code display shows where POST is failing. Write down the code and look it up in your motherboard manual (usually in back pages) or manufacturer website. If code changes rapidly, it may be proceeding normally. If stuck on one code, that's the failure point.

nodes.result: System is POSTing successfully! You can see BIOS or display output. If you're still having issues with booting to Windows/OS, that's a different problem (boot loader, OS corruption, or drive issues) - outside the scope of this POST diagnostic tool.

knowledge.text: POST (Power-On Self-Test) is complete when you see BIOS screen, manufacturer logo, or any display output. If you can enter BIOS (press Del/F2 at startup), POST is working. OS boot issues are a separate troubleshooting category.
